comments.commentBody: All of the reasons you cited made Trump the candidate. I assume you are a Jew as I am. I am fallen away big time and consider myself an aetheist. But when Trump made his announcement and dissed Mexicans, my conclusion was that an avowed racist is not qualified for the Oval Office. While the field of Republican hopefuls made criticizing him difficult, what rang the bell of his future, aside from great voter unrest with their lot in life, was the moral failure of both the opponents and the Republican party. When a prospective leader cannot disguise his bigotry, my fear is: We Jews are next. He opened the door to America first, nativism, fear of Muslims, and total negation of the Federal government. He even was quoted as saying that the little guys with hats he only trusted to count his money. That's badly disguised anti-Semitism and he opened the door to the disaffected at the very least distrusting Jews for the usual reasons down through the millenia, If you got it wrong about Trump's future, you overlooked his character deficiency as a self-blind narcissist.

Trump. The man with a plan. How wonderful he is, with his majestic hair, and his ability to go into a crowd of his followers, shot someone, and not get any backlash. Oh how wonderful his hair is, glowing with the prosperous smile. He truly can make America great again. Long live Lord Trump

"And the polls show him trailing by a wide margin in Wisconsin..."

I think the word you're looking for is "losing."

-dlj.
Well, there we go, Trump got his 35% after all.  So nothing in recent days really hurt him, that's how I read it.
It's because those white farmers want their cheap slave labor.

In an article elsewhere on the NYT on Melania Trump's being enlisted to help improve her husband's image with women, there was a telling statement ...

“Even Mr. Trump’s first wife, Ivana, who is the mother of his three oldest children, is speaking up for her ex-husband, praising him in an interview published Sunday in The New York Post, which has long been friendly to him. In the interview, she said she still advised her ex-husband, wished Melania ‘all the best’ and said Mr. Trump ‘loves women’ but is ‘not a feminist.’ … Yet in a sign of Mr. Trump’s complicated relationship with women, Ivana Trump’s staff later called the paper to say Mr. Trump was, in fact, a feminist, before calling again to say he was not — and then calling a final time to say he was, indeed, a feminist.”

It's the Cheese Head Factor.

Wisconsin has drifted right. Obviously with the popularity of Gov. Walker the state is much more conservative that it used to be.

However, the dairy industry still holds major sway. And the capitalists, big and small in Wisconsin want cheap labor. They don't want a wall on the Mexican border. You'll recall an audience member querying Trump about this at the town hall. Donald gave a very mediocre answer.

And so it goes with the Republican Party. They do not want to go along with President Obama and Senator McCain on a reasonable immigration plan. They want the status quo: no comprehensive immigration reform and no draconian Trump immigration plans either. Wisconsin wants and needs cheap labor.

How many of the dairymen give the workers healthcare in order that the spouses of the workers or female employees do not take Medicaid for prenatal care, as well as labor & delivery charges in a hospital? Of course, they gainsay taxes of any kind.

The Wisconsin Badgers out of liberal Madison have let the country down. Let's hope they atone by securing electoral votes for Mrs. Clinton.

Please regularly use the term "statistical model" instead of simply "model." After all, your analyses (i.e., results derived from fitting a statistical model to the data) are based on empirical data. Correct? Many untrained people dismiss anything based solely on a "model" as irrelevant.

Thanks for noting the different waves of19th century immigration into Wisconsin affecting Trump. Colin Woodard's new take on this phenomenon is in his book, "American Character," just published. Recommended.

Hey Nate,
Is Trump's performance an example of regression to the mean?

replies.commentBody:
Frankly, sir, your inability to fathom the signal differences between Marxism and socialism, leads me to wonder if you are actually a reader of the NYTimes.

Senator Sanders is a socialist.

There is zero connection between socialism and Marxism.

The fact is, socialist systems are widespread--and in constant use--in this country.

And, unless you limit your driving to your own driveway, you are an active participant in one--the streets and highways in this country are ALL socialist undertaking.

Ditto for your local fire department.

And public schools.

If you're going to use a word--it would be of real benefit to you to make sure your know what it means.

comments.commentBody: Years ago many former Democrats left the Party because it had gone too far left. Now that the real Marxist heart of the Party has been exposed by Sanders, and the Party has officially gone over the edge, more are leaving. A friend who just switched Parties explained it this way: Democrats have gone so far to the extreme left that they are running open Marxists for US president! In my lifetime, commie thugs with Sanders ideology vowed to bury us and the US Govt trained us to kill them and sent us overseas to do just that. While Reagan and GHWB were waging a brilliant war to defeat the evil Soviet Union, Sanders took his bride there on their honeymoon! If you thought Howard Dean was crazy - and he is - then Bernie Sanders belongs in a padded cell....along with much of the rest of the Democrat Party! Instead of promising a chicken in every pot....Sanders promise is a crazy comrade in every closet! And Hillary Clinton is so corrupt she makes John Edwards look ethical!

You article never mentioned the difference between primaries vs caucuses, or states where anyone can vote for either party vs states where only registered party members can vote in their own party. This could be significant because you reference Massachusetts several times yet I suspect voting there was heavily influenced by people crossing party lines just to mess up the vote for the other side.

Early and absentee voting has been going on in Wisconsin for two weeks. The GOP "anyone but Trump/vote Cruz to stop Trump" forces, led by downstate talk radio and Gov Walker, have been very active against him through that time - although not so openly until more recently on the part of Walker. I would think this would be reflected in the votes already cast.

Trump was not well organized in Wisconsin to begin with, and his rallies have not been the draw they had been elsewhere. Could it be those early/absentee voters were skewed anti-Trump, and so the polls now reflect that? I don't know if there is some way to assess this based on prior races etc., but wonder if it could mean a closer race than the media has been talking about.

The analysis is sound.  Trump has one of the strongest base available.  His supporters have the tendency of idolatry rather than rationality.  They haven't discovered that Trump could not walk on water. Losing WI will just make Trump limps into the convention as a wounded animal who will be looking for payback- an omen for the Republican party.

replies.commentBody: It ain't over 'til the fat lady of California sings.

comments.commentBody: Nice article.  Down here in Virginia, its article after article in the Wash Po screaming they are finally right and Trump is over!  All because he will lose Wisconsin...  Of course, none of them ever said Wisconsin was the "pivotal" state in the election process...  I thought it was Ohio... wait, Florida... wait, Texas....  wait - oh Wisconsin!  That's the ticket!!!
Trump voters are voting for Trump! Cruz voters are voting for a brokered convention to let Paul Ryan run for President.

replies.commentBody: So Tokyo, are you a member of the lower educated whites that you seem to know their reasoning. Well I am of that clan being a carpenter all my life. They work for cash under the table, and never show on the books so no one covers them with W/comp. People are finally noticing the quality of the work has gone down quite a bit in new homes. The last time I tried to bid on sub work for a builder he asked if I had Mexicans working for me and when I said no he said don't waste his time or mine. In 2005  I brought in over $300,000 , I haven't hit $100,000 in 5 years. You are the uneducated one I believe.
You cannot deny, though, that Trump is the one who brought the issue to the table.

comments.commentBody: A very interesting analysis.  It is very refreshing to see thoughtful and insightful explanations rather than politically inspired rhetoric.  It will be interesting to view the results of the Wisconsin primary in terms of this analysis.  So, the key result to watch is not that Mr. Trump wins but that he does not lose with less than 35%.  Maybe, this is what Mr. Trump means when he claims he will do very well in Wisconsin, as it seems rather unlikely that he will win.  Perhaps, Mr. Trump expects to lose with more than 35% and that Mr. Cruz will win with less than 44%?  Using this rationale, Mr. Kasich might likewise consider himself a winner, if his numbers come in higher than expected.

replies.commentBody: In the US a socialist might win if running against a fascist or a religious zealot. But it may come down to what other local elections and initiatives are Being voted on. For example, if marijuana legalization is being voted on in California, it might be favor the socialist by inducing more young voters and middle aged libertarians to cast a ballot helping him win that state. Similarly, the conservative southern states might try to pack their local ballots with anti-gay measures in order to bring out their religious base, but that might backfire by also motivating their more liberal and libertarian voters to also turn out.

comments.commentBody: Any state where Bernie Sanders is leading is an outlier by definition; America will never chose a socialist president in my lifetime at least (his support among millennials who still live in mom and dad's basement notwithstanding). That said, while Trump was behind Cruz by 10 points in Wisconsin last week, the latest ARG poll has Trump now leading by 10 points, with all other polls within the margin of error - a trend in Trump's favor. So jst maybe it is about "momentum" after all NYT.

replies.commentBody: Probably not, primarily because it's not relevant to the analysis.

replies.commentBody: The abolition movement was centered in New England, particularly in Massachucetts and the Boston area. So, yes, old stock Yankees led the fight for abolition.

Old stock Yankees supported abolitionism in the mid-19th century, civil rights in the 20th century, and are the supporters of Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton today. They used to be Republicans, but were discarded by the Reagan-Republicans, and now find their political home within the Democratic Party, ranging from centrists to the progressives.

A minority of old stock Protestants in all regions of the northeast supported abolition, and for a variety of reasons. Ohio and western New York stood on the front lines of the movement, except for people like William Lloyd Garrison.

comments.commentBody:
Well researched and written article with exception to this phrase....

"It was the old-stock Yankees who led the fight for abolition" They led the fight to force the South to remain in the Union-not fight for abolition.
